articles.headline: Rick Scott Drops Social Security From Plan as G.O.P. Retreats From Entitlement Cuts
articles.snippet: The backtracking by the Florida Republican came after bipartisan criticism and signaled how completely the G.O.P. has pulled away from calls to overhaul the nation’s entitlement programs.
articles.abstract: The backtracking by the Florida Republican came after bipartisan criticism and signaled how completely the G.O.P. has pulled away from calls to overhaul the nation’s entitlement programs.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Rick Scott of Florida finally recognized this week what leading figures in his party had been telling him for a year: Most Republicans no longer wish to discuss cutting Social Security and Medicare as a way to balance the federal budget and bring down the soaring debt.

articles.headline: U.S. and China Vie in Hazy Zone Where Balloons, U.F.O.s and Missiles Fly
articles.snippet: American officials are worried China is far along in developing military technology that operates in the unregulated high-altitude zone of “near space.”
articles.abstract: American officials are worried China is far along in developing military technology that operates in the unregulated high-altitude zone of “near space.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — During the Cold War, American strategists feared the Soviet Union was outpacing the United States in arms production, potentially leading to a so-called missile gap. Now, U.S. officials are worried about a literal gap called near space and China’s growing presence there.
articles.byline: By Edward Wong, Eric Schmitt and Julian E. Barnes

articles.headline: Norfolk Southern’s Profits and Accident Rates Rose in Recent Years
articles.snippet: Safety experts say a focus on financial returns may be partly to blame for derailments and accidents like the one in Ohio.
articles.abstract: Safety experts say a focus on financial returns may be partly to blame for derailments and accidents like the one in Ohio.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last month, as Norfolk Southern, one of the largest railroads in North America, reported record operating profits, Alan H. Shaw, its chief executive, told shareholders that the company’s service was “at the best it’s been in more than two years.”
articles.byline: By Peter Eavis and Mark Walker

articles.headline: Fetterman’s Disclosure of Depression Signals New Openness on Mental Health
articles.snippet: The Democratic senator from Pennsylvania is the latest public figure to disclose his mental health struggles, an indication of growing acceptance, though some stigma remains.
articles.abstract: The Democratic senator from Pennsylvania is the latest public figure to disclose his mental health struggles, an indication of growing acceptance, though some stigma remains.
articles.lead_paragraph: Lynn Rivers, a Democrat from Michigan, opened up about her diagnosis with bipolar disorder during a radio call-in show when she first ran for Congress. Her opponents had been hinting she had mental health problems. She decided, spur of the moment, to let it out.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Ellen Barry

articles.headline: Government Cracks Down on Crypto Industry With Flurry of Actions
articles.snippet: State and federal agencies have levied fines, brought new cases and issued policy statements to rein in freewheeling practices in recent weeks.
articles.abstract: State and federal agencies have levied fines, brought new cases and issued policy statements to rein in freewheeling practices in recent weeks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Cryptocurrency executives hoped that 2023 would herald a new beginning after a year of disastrous setbacks. Instead, the industry has found itself on the receiving end of an aggressive government crackdown.

articles.headline: Blinken Has Tense Meeting With Chinese Official Amid Spy Balloon Furor
articles.snippet: The meeting resumed diplomatic contact between Washington and Beijing that had been frozen since the U.S. shot down a Chinese spy balloon.
articles.abstract: The meeting resumed diplomatic contact between Washington and Beijing that had been frozen since the U.S. shot down a Chinese spy balloon.
articles.lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken held what American officials described as a confrontational meeting with his Chinese counterpart on Saturday night in Munich, warning him that the flight of a Chinese surveillance balloon across the United States “must never happen again.”
articles.byline: By Michael Crowley and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: ‘Brainwashing a Generation’: British Schools Combat Andrew Tate’s Views
articles.snippet: Alarmed by an online personality’s popularity among their students, educators are mobilizing to combat the sexism he promotes.
articles.abstract: Alarmed by an online personality’s popularity among their students, educators are mobilizing to combat the sexism he promotes.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
articles.byline: By Emma Bubola and Isabella Kwai

articles.headline: Haley Walks Treacherous Road for G.O.P. Women
articles.snippet: Nikki Haley’s presidential campaign is a major test of her party’s views on sexism and female leaders. Just don’t call it identity politics.
articles.abstract: Nikki Haley’s presidential campaign is a major test of her party’s views on sexism and female leaders. Just don’t call it identity politics.
articles.lead_paragraph: EXETER, N.H. — According to Nikki Haley, bullies are best subdued by a counter kick — in heels. Achieving a new vision for the country requires the leadership of a “tough-as-nails woman.” And generational change starts with putting a “badass woman in the White House.”
articles.byline: By Katie Glueck and Lisa Lerer

articles.headline: As the Pandemic Swept America, Deaths in Prisons Rose Nearly 50 Percent
articles.snippet: ‌The first comprehensive data on prison fatalities in the Covid era sheds new light on where and why prisoners were especially vulnerable.
articles.abstract: ‌The first comprehensive data on prison fatalities in the Covid era sheds new light on where and why prisoners were especially vulnerable.
articles.lead_paragraph: Deaths in state and federal prisons across America rose nearly 50 percent during the first year of the pandemic, and in six states they more than doubled, according to the first comprehensive data on prison fatalities in the era of Covid-19.
articles.byline: By Jennifer Valentino-DeVries and Allie Pitchon

articles.headline: Bruce’s Beach Was Hailed as a Reparations Model. Then the Family Sold It.
articles.snippet: The Bruce family won the return of oceanfront land near Los Angeles seized nearly a century ago. Their decision to sell for $20 million set off a different debate about reparations.
articles.abstract: The Bruce family won the return of oceanfront land near Los Angeles seized nearly a century ago. Their decision to sell for $20 million set off a different debate about reparations.
articles.lead_paragraph: MANHATTAN BEACH, Calif. — On a bright day last summer, Anthony Bruce stood on a patch of grassy land perched on the Pacific Ocean. As deep blue waves gently dissolved onto the shoreline behind him, the Los Angeles County Registrar-Recorder handed Mr. Bruce a document transferring this piece of oceanfront property to his family — 95 years after they lost it.

articles.headline: One Year Into War, Putin Is Crafting the Russia He Craves
articles.snippet: In Ukraine, President Vladimir V. Putin’s invasion has met setback after setback. But its effect at home has been very different.
articles.abstract: In Ukraine, President Vladimir V. Putin’s invasion has met setback after setback. But its effect at home has been very different.
articles.lead_paragraph: The grievances, paranoia and imperialist mind-set that drove President Vladimir V. Putin to invade Ukraine have seeped deep into Russian life after a year of war — a broad, if uneven, societal upheaval that has left the Russian leader more dominant than ever at home.
articles.byline: By Anton Troianovski, Valerie Hopkins and Nanna Heitmann

articles.headline: U.S. Warnings to China on Arms Aid for Russia’s War Portend Global Rift
articles.snippet: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken says Washington has indications that Beijing is strongly considering giving military aid to Moscow for the war in Ukraine.
articles.abstract: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken says Washington has indications that Beijing is strongly considering giving military aid to Moscow for the war in Ukraine.
articles.lead_paragraph: MADRID — When the top foreign policy officials from the United States and China appeared this weekend at Europe’s premier global security conference, both stressed that their governments were not seeking a new Cold War.

articles.headline: Biden Drawing Up a 2024 Playbook That Looks a Lot Like 2020’s
articles.snippet: President Biden’s strategy is to frame the race as a contest between a seasoned leader and a conspiracy-minded opposition, while batting away concerns about his age.
articles.abstract: President Biden’s strategy is to frame the race as a contest between a seasoned leader and a conspiracy-minded opposition, while batting away concerns about his age.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Forget the Wilmington basement. This time he will have a Rose Garden. And Air Force One and a big white mansion and all the other advantages of incumbency in a year when he is not forced by a pandemic to stick to streaming from downstairs.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker, Reid J. Epstein and Lisa Lerer

articles.headline: A Fraught New Frontier in Telehealth: Ketamine
articles.snippet: With loosened rules around remote prescriptions, a psychedelic-like drug has become a popular treatment for mental health conditions. But a boom in at-home use has outpaced evidence of safety.
articles.abstract: With loosened rules around remote prescriptions, a psychedelic-like drug has become a popular treatment for mental health conditions. But a boom in at-home use has outpaced evidence of safety.
articles.lead_paragraph: For Greg Rice, ketamine was transformative. The drug, approved decades ago to sedate patients during surgery, was increasingly being used to treat mental health conditions like his depression.

articles.headline: Hedge Fund Billionaire Extracts Billions More to Retire
articles.snippet: Bridgewater’s founder, Ray Dalio, retired last year after months of negotiations that guaranteed him a gigantic exit package.
articles.abstract: Bridgewater’s founder, Ray Dalio, retired last year after months of negotiations that guaranteed him a gigantic exit package.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Ray Dalio, the multibillionaire founder of the world’s biggest hedge fund, Bridgewater Associates, announced his retirement in October, both he and the firm he founded more than four decades ago treated the moment as celebratory.
articles.byline: By Rob Copeland and Maureen Farrell

articles.headline: Supreme Court to Hear Case That Targets a Legal Shield of Tech Giants
articles.snippet: The justices are set to hear a case challenging Section 230, a law that protects Google, Facebook and others from lawsuits over what their users post online.
articles.abstract: The justices are set to hear a case challenging Section 230, a law that protects Google, Facebook and others from lawsuits over what their users post online.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nohemi Gonzalez, a 23-year-old California college student, was studying abroad in Paris in November 2015 when she was among the 130 people killed in a coordinated series of terrorist attacks throughout the city.

articles.headline: They Were Married. They Shared a Trench. They Died in It Together.
articles.snippet: Taras and Olha Melster signed up to help the war effort. Like many other urban professionals in Ukraine, they never expected to be sent to the front line.
articles.abstract: Taras and Olha Melster signed up to help the war effort. Like many other urban professionals in Ukraine, they never expected to be sent to the front line.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
articles.byline: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Ivor Prickett

articles.headline: With an Eye on China, Philippines Moves Closer to U.S. Interests
articles.snippet: Driven by worry about China’s aggression, President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. has adopted the most muscular foreign policy approach that the Philippines has seen in close to a decade.
articles.abstract: Driven by worry about China’s aggression, President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. has adopted the most muscular foreign policy approach that the Philippines has seen in close to a decade.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, the Philippines largely stood by as Chinese forces rammed its fishing vessels and occupied the reefs and shoals that once belonged to the Southeast Asian nation.
articles.byline: By Sui-Lee Wee and Camille Elemia

articles.headline: In Mississippi’s Capital, Old Racial Divides Take New Forms
articles.snippet: A plan by Republican lawmakers to set up a new court system served by a state-run police force for parts of mainly Black Jackson has become a flash point for racial and political divisions.
articles.abstract: A plan by Republican lawmakers to set up a new court system served by a state-run police force for parts of mainly Black Jackson has become a flash point for racial and political divisions.
articles.lead_paragraph: JACKSON, Miss. — Mississippi’s struggling capital has been a favored target of Republican leaders since the G.O.P. took total control of the state a decade ago. But perhaps none of the slings and arrows flung at Jackson has provoked as much outrage as the one the state House of Representatives loosed earlier this month.
